audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a short, electronic intro, seemingly for a website. This shifts into a person, presumably a female speaker, praising a technique before introducing a question on karma with a conversational tone. An additional female voice responds with the expression "Hmm".

The clip starts with a female speaker, using a curious and questioning tone, beginning a conversation on karma in day-to-day life, specifically how past karmic actions are brought along to the present. A male speaker responds with interest, noting it's a "good question."

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining that "when the soul leaves the body, it doesn't go alone, the mind also goes with the soul," and goes on to describe that "ourself is made up of three parts," and talks about mind, soul, and karma. The speaker speaks in a calm and informative tone. The clip ends with a deep humming or chanting sound in the background.

The audio features a single male speaker discussing the nature of karma, describing it as potentially physical or verbal, but originating in thought. He explains that the quality of the thought determines the quality of the sanskar and the karm, classifying them as "good, bad, neutral, devotional." He notes that intensity matters and various actions can be judged as 'good' to varying degrees, and that all actions are impressed or recorded in the mind. Describing the mind as having levels of subtlety, he explains that because the medium in which the karma is being recorded is so subtle, the mind can record an infinite amount of information, since every soul is eternal with unlimited past karma, all recorded in our minds - this he calls 'sanchit karma'.

A male speaker introduces the concept of "Kriyaman Karma" as the karma we're performing in this life. He explains that our previous lives' karma is also stored, like on a hard drive, deep in our unconscious mind, called "Sanchit Karma", which goes with us from life to life. He then transitions to a different model to think of it, mentioning "Karan Sharir", where all those "Sanskar" become the cause of our next incarnation.

A male speaker discusses the concept of "Sanchit Karma", a portion of which becomes "Prarabdh", our destiny. He explains that we are given a part of it to "bhog" to undergo good and bad consequences in this life. He also mentions that "simultaneously we're performing new Karma".

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing destiny, explaining that while some things are predetermined, like birth and uncontrollable events, not everything is. His tone is thoughtful and explanatory.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing karma, stating that "thoughts, actions, words" and other things are not destined, explaining how people create new karma. The speaker continues, talking about "sanchit, prarabdh, and kriyamana karm." A female speaker responds in agreement and says it is "very interesting" to learn about things people are not aware of in their lives.

The clip begins with a female speaker discussing the importance of being aware of one's actions. She speaks in a conversational tone, transitioning into a question about a day-to-day routine. A male speaker then responds, describing his role as a "pracharak," someone who teaches others what he's learned from his Guru. He speaks with a gentle, warm tone, explaining how sharing this knowledge has positively impacted his life and allows him to continually review it himself. He concludes with the phrase, "It's a big blessing."

The audio begins with one male speaker explaining how he travels constantly around the US giving lectures in Hindu temples, and occasionally other venues and people's homes. He mentions staying in a different home every night and staying with people so they can ask questions and to inspire them on their spiritual path, and teach them ways to integrate spirituality into daily life. He then states part of his day is spent with people, followed by someone saying "yeah."

The clip begins with a male speaker describing his daily routine, mentioning evening lectures or meditation programs, his morning meditation practice, and listening to "Kirtan" followed by "Roop Dhyan." He then mentions doing the same before going to sleep at night. His speaking tone is calm and measured.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing his daily routine, mentioning exercise, yoga, walking, jogging, and studies. He speaks in a calm and informative tone, describing his administrative tasks and future program planning. The speaker then mentions taking breaks, including going to India twice a year for meditation intensives.

The audio clip features two speakers, one male and one female, engaged in conversation. The male speaker describes looking forward to certain things and the female speaker remarks on the associated work. The male speaker clarifies he enjoys the work, after which the conversation shifts to the reason for his presence in Dallas. He explains he is part of an affiliated center of Radha Madhav Dham and is giving a series of lectures on the leelas of Sri Krishna. The female speaker notes her interest in Radha Govind Dham in Irving, Texas. She compliments the male speakerâ€™s voice, then asks him to sing a small kirtan.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating he can sing a few lines of a "bhajan" composed by his "guruji", proceeding to sing in a devotional tone, chanting "Radhe Radhe Govind, Govind Radhe". The song has a gentle, soothing melody, presumably accompanied by harmonium or similar drone-based instruments. Upon completion, the male speaker says a phrase. Then, a female voice expresses appreciation, saying "Beautifully sung", followed by "Thanks a lot".

The audio clip begins with a female speaker expressing happiness about having the "pleasure to talk" and "to hear your bhajan a little bit," describing it as "so". The overall tone is cheerful and appreciative.

The audio clip begins with a female voice suggesting that viewers visit Radha Govinda in Irving, Texas, to enjoy lectures and bhajans. Her tone is informative and inviting. The clip concludes with music, which sounds like Indian devotional music, with a peaceful and reflective mood. The main instrument appears to be a harmonium, possibly accompanied by singing. An automated voice then says "Thank you".
